BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1914.

Hopkins Team Leads in Its Class at the
Famous Philadelphia Games—Oxford-Penn Relay Feature.

Capt. Butts Sutton's Twelve Loses an
Important Lacrosse Contest to
the Brown and White.

Capt. Harry Wagner's picked relay four won its mile relay race in
the Pennsylvania relays on Saturday
in Philadelphia. Pittsburgh, Lafayette, Franklin and Marshall,
Haverford, New York University
and New York Law School were
the other contestants, but Hopkins
found them easy opponents.
Claude I. Uhler held the field nicely on the first relay, and ex-Capt.
Herbert E. Catlin gave Capt. H.
Milton Wagner the lead which the
latter increased. Huntley Lloyd,
Hopkins' most famous quartermiler, had an easy time, as he simply strided through his distance,
breasting the tape in 3.34.
Hopkins has a fine record at the
Penn games. In 1898 the first
Black and Blue victory was recorded, when they traveled a mile in
3.4375. In 1899 the time was
5; 1901, 3.423/5 ;
/
5 ; 1900, 3.363
/
3.413
1913, 3.30-Y5 ; and 1914, 3.34.
The feature of the meet was the
Oxford-Pennsylvania four-mile relay, which the English team won in
record-breaking time. The Britishers went the distance in 18 minutes
5 seconds off
/
5 seconds, clipping 31
the Penn record. The race was a
stirring one and thrilled the 18,0o0
spectators. Oxford only won by a
foot.
After the games Referee Sullivan
said: "It was the most wonderful
finish I have ever seen in more than
25 years of athletics. Penn ran a
•great race against wonderful stars."

Lehigh defeated the 'Varsity lacrosse team on Saturday at South
Bethlehem, Pa.; the score was 6 to
4. The game was played in a
downpour of rain.
Just whether Hopkins is put out
of the race for the championship of
the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
—the title it now holds—is a point
that has not been decided. Lehigh
claims that the Black and Blue is
out of the race, but Hopkins' backers say that should the 'Varsity defeat Swarthmore, and Swarthmore
defeat Lehigh, Hopkins would still
have as good a claim to the title as
Lehigh. Lehigh plays Swarthmore
on Saturday.
Johns Hopkins had Lehigh on the
go the first ten minutes of play, and
their vigorous atack resulted in two
goals by Hollyday and Troxell.
Then play changed into Hopkins'
territory and the Lehighattack kept
up a perfect rain of shots against
Goalkeeper Sears. He did heroic
work. First Dunn shot a goal on
a pretty pass from Sanchez, then
Sanchez ran half the length of the
field, dodging cleverly, and netted
the shot that tied the score.
Shortly after this, White banged
a swift one at Sears, which glanced
from his stick into the net. Hopkins evened up at the start of the
second period when Knipp passed
to Troxell, who ran to the crease
and banged the ball in. Mayer put
Lehigh into the lead again. Sears
again stopped the ball, but it rolled
into the net. At this time Lehigh's
defense was working like a machine
and Hopkins seldom had a chance
to try to score.
Dunn received the ball as it seesawed up the field and shot it
straight across to Buck, who was
free. It was an easy shot for Buck.
Sanchez scored the last goal for Lehigh. The line-up:

The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
the Phi Beta Kappa Society—the
Alpha Chapter of Maryland—elected new members on Friday. Dr.
Wilfred P. Mustard, secretary of
the Chapter, notified the new members of their election.
The initiation of the new men
will take place in McCoy Hall on
next Saturday, May 2, and will be
immediately followed by the annual
dinner of the Chapter, at which the
new members will be guests. The
speaker at this dinner will be Henry
Holt, the publisher, who was elected
an honorary member of the Chapter.
The only election from the faculty of the University was that of Dr.
Leonard George Rowntree, associate professor of experimental therapeutics. There were six or seven
men elected from the graduate and
medical departments, but the exact
list of these men could not be secured for this issue.
In the undergraduate department,
eight seniors—one-sixth of the
graduating class — were elected to
membership. These are: Lawson
Wilkins, Aaron Schaffer, Albert L.
Hammond, Steuart D'Ohle White,
Carl Jefferson \Veber, N. B. Herman, M. H. Lauchheimer and Lawrence Getz.
Lawson Wilkins probably holds
the highest record for scholarship
during the four years. He has refrained from the distractions of student "activities," both in mental and
physical lines, and his high standing
is the result.
Aaron Schaffer has also been one
of the leaders of the class, as far
as scholarship is concerned. He has
also played a paft in the affairs of
the Grotius Society and the Chess
Club. He is a member of THE
NEWS-LF:TTER Board.
Albert L. Hammond is a member
of the Grotius Society, Student
Council, Debating Council, class and
intercollegiate debating teams, captain of the tennis team and editor
of the 1914 Hullabaloo.
Steuart D. White won the Adams
Medal, and was a member of both
junior and senior debating teams.

Some patriotic student at Yale
leaned out of his dormitory window
last Tuesday: when news that four
American marines had been killed
at Vera Cruz and shot his pistol in
the air. In a few minutes, according to press dispatches, there were
several hundred men on the campus,
and talk of enlistment and "going
to Mexico" was rife. No organization was formed, but Yale is
ready to go to war.
Stories have also gone out from
several other colleges that students
were prepared to enlist at a minute's
notice. The University of Chicago,
it is said, announced itself as willing
to confer the A. B. degree on any
senior whose enlistment and service
might compel his leaving the university. Boston Tech., too, has a
large -army," and half a dozen institutions in New York and New England are anxious to lay down
books and .take up guns at a moment's notice.
There has been no activity in
this line at Johns Hopkins, but the
"Hopkins Army of 1898" is read'lv
recalled. In the couple of weeks
preceding the Spanish War, Harvard, Yale and Hopkins were leaders in the movement to form volunteer companies. The martial zeal
shown by the undergraduate body
attracted widespread comment—the
New York Evening Press even saying that Hopkins had 1,000 men
ready to go to the front.
A company of about fifty was
formed and regular drills were held
in the cage under the unofficial supervision of officers of the State
militia. When is was seen, however, that the country's regular
troops were sufficient for the war,
the Hopkins company gradually lost
interest and became automatically
disbanded. The event, nevertheless,
furnished conversationa-1 matter for
many months, and gave rise, among
other things, to a poem by Dr.
John C.. French, then a senior.
"Major-General" French's verses,
published in the 1899 Hullabaloo,
were :

Baseball and Pushball Called Off.

Rain made cancellation of the
Hopkins-Western Maryland baseball
game and the sophomore-freshman
pushball contest necessary.
The interclass event will be staged
at a later date, to be announced by
the Student Council. The sophs
and freshies held practices that
were interesting and exciting on
Thursday and Friday, and were disappointed in not being able to get
together on Saturday.
Hopkins Men in the War.

The hospital corps of Gen. Villa's
Constitutionalist Army is in charge
of a Mexican graduate of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School.
It is said,that the organization of
this department is superior to that
of the actual fighting forces. The
Hopkins doctor has a number of
ambulances, an excellent supply of
medicines and cots and a welltrained corps of assistants and
nurses. Villa is very proud of the
department.

The debaters of the Grotius Society were defeated on Friday night
at Philadelphia for the third consecutive time. The question debated was: "Resolved, that the candidates for the Presidency of the
United States should be chosen by
direct primaries rather than by
party conventions as at present."
The Hopkins men presented a better case, so far as a statement of
convincing facts was concerned, but
their arguments were not as logically arranged as were those of their
opponents, and much of the strength
of their position was thus forfeited.
The Zelos who spoke for the affirmative were: G. P. Williams, S.
S. Szlapka and C. B. Hutchings.
The Grotius representatives spoke
in the following order; I. W. Nachlas, A. Schaffer and T. J. Tingley.
The judges were Professor Fritz
and Messrs. A. E. and K. R.
Alden.
Although the vote was decisive,
the debate was by no means a onesided affair, and the judges admitted that the decision was close.
The Grotius team remained in
Philadelphia to see our relay team
perform at the Penn meet, and returned to Baltimore late Saturday.

that President Wilson, the former

Irony From John Bull.

Mr. Henry E. Huntington's recent purchase from the Duke of
Devonshire of an almost priceless
collection of Caxtons, Shakespeare
folios and old plays brings to New
York still more of the treasures
which England has regarded as national possessions.
The London Globe, noted for its
irony, remarked:
"Some enterprising firm had better start cheap excursions to America, so that we can see the. old masters occasionally."
The, New York Telegram, answering the British press which bewailed the denuding of English
galleries and libraries by American
millionaires, said:
"Caxton, like Milton or Shakespeare, is as much an American
heritage as an English one; and it
is absurd for Englishmen, when in
good humor with us, to insist upon
the unity of certain preponderating
elements in our races and, when in
bad humor, to squeal if we get a
picture or so, or a manuscript from
some obscure, poverty-stricken or
whining peer.
"Many of the pictures which
have come over to us, and the loss
of which was bewailed as 'national,'
belonged to private persons and were
immured in country homes. They
had been obtained, moreover, by
purchase, in many cases, from foreign countries—from Holland, from
France and from Italy. It is no
terrible crime to sell to a foreign
country that which has been bought
from one. While bewailing the departure of art objects from England, the English sentimentalists
forget the purchase of the Elgin
marbles. These comprise no less a
treasure than the elaborately and
beautifully sculptured frieze of the
Parthenon, which Lord Elgin
bought from the Greek Government for the sum of i40,000. This
action has been denounced as vandalism ; but, (respite the denunciations, no English Government has
ever has the courage to propose
their restoration to Athens.
"It all depends, then, on whose
ox is gored."

Baseball is more subject to outside
influences than any other college
sport. The remarkable growth of the
great national game has been accompanied by an increasing lack of
ethics, and the college players, given
to a certain amount of emulation,
are beginning to adopt the spirit of
play shown by the professionals on
the diamond.
Professional baseball, at bottom,
is commercial; its primary object
is to make money for its backers.
Money can best be made when the
crowds are pleased, and to please
the crowds games must be won, no
matter by what means. And some
of these means have become objectionable. "Little tricks of the
trade," so to speak, have been employed to outwit opponents and win
games. Unfortunately, too, these
objectionable features have crept into the college game. Many persons
have deplored their introduction,
but have been unable to direct concerted corrective measures against
them.
The situation has reached that
point where some organized effort
must be made to get rid of the bad
features, and to this end a special
committee appointed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association
has made a study of conditions and
published a report in which recommendations are made that will tend
to prevent the introduction of the
so-called "professional spirit"into the
college sport. THE NEWS-LETTER

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 27, 1914.

THE N. C. A. ASSOCIATION
Recommendations and Regulations Intended for Adoption by American
College Baseball Teams.

The National Collegiate Athletic
Association, to which Dr. Ronald
T. Abercrombie is the Hopkins representative, has formulated the following recommendations and regulations which are intended for adoption by American college baseball
teams. The rules were prepared by
a special committee which studied
the baseball situation, and were accepted by the Association. It is
hoped that they will be put in force
throughout the country. The report of the committee follows:

the batsman or any member of the opposing team.
Second—No member .of either team
shall call or shout during the game to
any member of the opposing team, except to caution him against some danger,
nor behave in any indecorous or unseemly manner.
Third—There shall be no oral coaching from the bench.
Fourth — The so-called "encouragement of the pitcher" from the outfield
shall be stopped, or at least minimized,
since we believe that the shouting of remarks in endless iteration is not only
disagreeable to the spectators, but it is
disconcerting rather than helpful to the
pitcher. In general, it amounts merely to
senseless noise, and is quite unworthy
of college-bred men. Whatever "encouragement" or "support" the pitcher
may need can be quietly given from the
infield.
Fifth — The umpire shall warn any
player violating any of these rules, and
on a second offense shall exclude him
from the game.
Sixth—That in general the attention
of students be called to the importance
of courtesy on the part of the home institution to the visiting team, a courtesy
which will forbid such cheering, singing
or chatter as are designed at critical
moments to "rattle" the visiting team.
A baseball game is a splendid contest
of skill between two opposing nines, before an academic throng of spectators;
it is not a contest between a visiting
team and a local team assisted by a disorderly rabble. It is delightful when, as
often happens, a fine play by the visiting
team is as heartily applauded as a similar
play by the home team.
To the end that these principles, if endorsed by this Association, be a real
force and not a mere brutum fulmen, we
recommend that, if adopted, this report
be printed in separate form and copies
be sent by the secretary to the presidents, the deans, the athletic directors
or similar officers, the chairmen of faculty committees on athletic sports and to
the editors of .undergraduate publications of all colleges and universities aid
also to the leading preparatory schools
in the United States, with a formal request for action thereon and a report of
such action to the secretary of the Association.
Lours BErrry. JR., Chairman.

Your committee has for the time being nothing to do with the difficult question of eligibility, nor with summer ball
in its relation to amateur sport. It is
concerned with what is appropriate and
desirable in the conduct of the game
itself, in order that the manners of
officials, players and spectators may be
uniformly those of a gentleman, where
the highest ideals of fairness and sportsmanship shall be maintained, as is so admirably done in intercollegiate tennis.
We do not think that anything should
be recommended which would diminish
the virility of the game, or lessen the
scope of individual skill, or of clever
team-work, but we earnestly contend
that strategy must not deteriorate into
trickery, and that the rules of the game
must be observed, not only in letter,
but in spirit as well.
To this end, your committee recommends:
First—The strict enforcement of Rule
58 of the official rule book, which defines the coaching rules at first and
third bases, explicitly providing that "the
coacher shall be restricted to coaching
the base runner only, and shall not address remarks except to the base runner,
and then only in words of assistance and
direction in running bases. He shall not
by words or signs incite or try to incite
the spectators to demonstrations, and
shall not use language which will in any
manner refer to or reflect upon a player
of the opposite club, the umpire or the
spectators."
Second—The strict enforcement of

YALE WANTS TO CO TO WAR
(Continuedfrom page I.)
'I heir captain marched them around the
cage,
And marched them around again.
Thus some grew weary in one short day
(Though the nation had need of
them),
And these, when they softly stole away,
Left the company less by ten.
And ninety men of determined minds,
Ready to do and dare,
Lined up in the cage at the captain's
word,
And drilled with a martial air.
When some went out to an army camp,
To learn of the soldiers' fare—
When the company met for drill next
day,
There were only eighty there.
IV.
But the hearts of the eighty were firm
and strong,
And keen was their thirst for war;
Till a soldier who passed that way one
day,
Looked in at the open door,
And swore, with a laugh, that so awkward a squad,
He never had seen before.
This saddened the hearts of the eighty
men,
And ten of them drilled no more.
V.
Into the cage the seventy went,
Filled with a proud disdain;
"Let the faint-hearted go," they said,
"The best of us still remain."

BALTIMORE

But the news was spread of a mighty
fleet
Just sailed from the coast of Spain,
And ten of those who had marched out
that day
Were given and awful pain.
VI.
But sixty remained who laughed at fear,
And their hearts were light and gay,
Till the captain was asked by a practical
one,
"How much is a soldier's pay?"
And the captain, a blunt, straightforward
man,
Told them the truth that day;
The. company met for drill again,
But ten more stayed away.
VII.
'Twas thus with the noble company
That answered their country's call,
Their hearts were brave and their courage strong,
Even to fight and fall.
But numbers and patience and courage
alike
Faded from great to small,
For every day ten slippel away,
Until there were none at all.
VIII.
All honor those hundred Hopkins men,
That little, devoted band,
Though their names are not written in
brass and stone,
Nor lauded throughout the land;
For against the hungry tooth of time
Bravely they made their stand,
Till at last in their decimated ranks
There was not one left to disband.

Hopkins Team Leads in Its Class at the
Famous Philadelphia Games—Oxford-Penn Relay Feature.

Capt. Butts Sutton's Twelve Loses an
Important Lacrosse Contest to
the Brown and White.

Capt. Harry Wagner's picked relay four won its mile relay race in
the Pennsylvania relays on Saturday
in Philadelphia. Pittsburgh, Lafayette, Franklin and Marshall,
Haverford, New York University
and New York Law School were
the other contestants, but Hopkins
found them easy opponents.
Claude I. Uhler held the field nicely on the first relay, and ex-Capt.
Herbert E. Catlin gave Capt. H.
Milton Wagner the lead which the
latter increased. Huntley Lloyd,
Hopkins' most famous quartermiler, had an easy time, as he simply strided through his distance,
breasting the tape in 3.34.
Hopkins has a fine record at the
Penn games. In 1898 the first
Black and Blue victory was recorded, when they traveled a mile in
3.4375. In 1899 the time was
5; 1901, 3.423/5 ;
/
5 ; 1900, 3.363
/
3.413
1913, 3.30-Y5 ; and 1914, 3.34.
The feature of the meet was the
Oxford-Pennsylvania four-mile relay, which the English team won in
record-breaking time. The Britishers went the distance in 18 minutes
5 seconds off
/
5 seconds, clipping 31
the Penn record. The race was a
stirring one and thrilled the 18,0o0
spectators. Oxford only won by a
foot.
After the games Referee Sullivan
said: "It was the most wonderful
finish I have ever seen in more than
25 years of athletics. Penn ran a
•great race against wonderful stars."

Lehigh defeated the 'Varsity lacrosse team on Saturday at South
Bethlehem, Pa.; the score was 6 to
4. The game was played in a
downpour of rain.
Just whether Hopkins is put out
of the race for the championship of
the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
—the title it now holds—is a point
that has not been decided. Lehigh
claims that the Black and Blue is
out of the race, but Hopkins' backers say that should the 'Varsity defeat Swarthmore, and Swarthmore
defeat Lehigh, Hopkins would still
have as good a claim to the title as
Lehigh. Lehigh plays Swarthmore
on Saturday.
Johns Hopkins had Lehigh on the
go the first ten minutes of play, and
their vigorous atack resulted in two
goals by Hollyday and Troxell.
Then play changed into Hopkins'
territory and the Lehighattack kept
up a perfect rain of shots against
Goalkeeper Sears. He did heroic
work. First Dunn shot a goal on
a pretty pass from Sanchez, then
Sanchez ran half the length of the
field, dodging cleverly, and netted
the shot that tied the score.
Shortly after this, White banged
a swift one at Sears, which glanced
from his stick into the net. Hopkins evened up at the start of the
second period when Knipp passed
to Troxell, who ran to the crease
and banged the ball in. Mayer put
Lehigh into the lead again. Sears
again stopped the ball, but it rolled
into the net. At this time Lehigh's
defense was working like a machine
and Hopkins seldom had a chance
to try to score.
Dunn received the ball as it seesawed up the field and shot it
straight across to Buck, who was
free. It was an easy shot for Buck.
Sanchez scored the last goal for Lehigh. The line-up:

The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
the Phi Beta Kappa Society—the
Alpha Chapter of Maryland—elected new members on Friday. Dr.
Wilfred P. Mustard, secretary of
the Chapter, notified the new members of their election.
The initiation of the new men
will take place in McCoy Hall on
next Saturday, May 2, and will be
immediately followed by the annual
dinner of the Chapter, at which the
new members will be guests. The
speaker at this dinner will be Henry
Holt, the publisher, who was elected
an honorary member of the Chapter.
The only election from the faculty of the University was that of Dr.
Leonard George Rowntree, associate professor of experimental therapeutics. There were six or seven
men elected from the graduate and
medical departments, but the exact
list of these men could not be secured for this issue.
In the undergraduate department,
eight seniors—one-sixth of the
graduating class — were elected to
membership. These are: Lawson
Wilkins, Aaron Schaffer, Albert L.
Hammond, Steuart D'Ohle White,
Carl Jefferson \Veber, N. B. Herman, M. H. Lauchheimer and Lawrence Getz.
Lawson Wilkins probably holds
the highest record for scholarship
during the four years. He has refrained from the distractions of student "activities," both in mental and
physical lines, and his high standing
is the result.
Aaron Schaffer has also been one
of the leaders of the class, as far
as scholarship is concerned. He has
also played a paft in the affairs of
the Grotius Society and the Chess
Club. He is a member of THE

of the Grotius Society, Student

intercollegiate debating teams, captain of the tennis team and editor
of the 1914 Hullabaloo.
Steuart D. White won the Adams
Medal, and was a member of both
junior and senior debating teams.

Some patriotic student at Yale
leaned out of his dormitory window
last Tuesday: when news that four
American marines had been killed
at Vera Cruz and shot his pistol in
the air. In a few minutes, according to press dispatches, there were
several hundred men on the campus,
and talk of enlistment and "going
to Mexico" was rife. No organization was formed, but Yale is
ready to go to war.
Stories have also gone out from
several other colleges that students
were prepared to enlist at a minute's
notice. The University of Chicago,
it is said, announced itself as willing
to confer the A. B. degree on any
senior whose enlistment and service
might compel his leaving the university. Boston Tech., too, has a
large -army," and half a dozen institutions in New York and New England are anxious to lay down
books and .take up guns at a moment's notice.
There has been no activity in
this line at Johns Hopkins, but the
"Hopkins Army of 1898" is read'lv
recalled. In the couple of weeks
preceding the Spanish War, Harvard, Yale and Hopkins were leaders in the movement to form volunteer companies. The martial zeal
shown by the undergraduate body
attracted widespread comment—the
New York Evening Press even saying that Hopkins had 1,000 men
ready to go to the front.
A company of about fifty was
formed and regular drills were held
in the cage under the unofficial supervision of officers of the State
militia. When is was seen, however, that the country's regular
troops were sufficient for the war,
the Hopkins company gradually lost
interest and became automatically
disbanded. The event, nevertheless,
furnished conversationa-1 matter for
many months, and gave rise, among
other things, to a poem by Dr.
John C.. French, then a senior.
"Major-General" French's verses,
published in the 1899 Hullabaloo,
were :

Baseball and Pushball Called Off.

Rain made cancellation of the
Hopkins-Western Maryland baseball
game and the sophomore-freshman
pushball contest necessary.
The interclass event will be staged
at a later date, to be announced by
the Student Council. The sophs
and freshies held practices that
were interesting and exciting on
Thursday and Friday, and were disappointed in not being able to get
together on Saturday.
Hopkins Men in the War.

The hospital corps of Gen. Villa's
Constitutionalist Army is in charge
of a Mexican graduate of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School.
It is said,that the organization of
this department is superior to that
of the actual fighting forces. The
Hopkins doctor has a number of
ambulances, an excellent supply of
medicines and cots and a welltrained corps of assistants and
nurses. Villa is very proud of the
department.

The debaters of the Grotius Society were defeated on Friday night
at Philadelphia for the third consecutive time. The question debated was: "Resolved, that the candidates for the Presidency of the
United States should be chosen by
direct primaries rather than by
party conventions as at present."
The Hopkins men presented a better case, so far as a statement of
convincing facts was concerned, but
their arguments were not as logically arranged as were those of their
opponents, and much of the strength
of their position was thus forfeited.
The Zelos who spoke for the affirmative were: G. P. Williams, S.
S. Szlapka and C. B. Hutchings.
The Grotius representatives spoke
in the following order; I. W. Nachlas, A. Schaffer and T. J. Tingley.
The judges were Professor Fritz
and Messrs. A. E. and K. R.
Alden.
Although the vote was decisive,
the debate was by no means a onesided affair, and the judges admitted that the decision was close.
The Grotius team remained in
Philadelphia to see our relay team
perform at the Penn meet, and returned to Baltimore late Saturday.

Irony From John Bull.

Mr. Henry E. Huntington's recent purchase from the Duke of
Devonshire of an almost priceless
collection of Caxtons, Shakespeare
folios and old plays brings to New
York still more of the treasures
which England has regarded as national possessions.
The London Globe, noted for its
irony, remarked:
"Some enterprising firm had better start cheap excursions to America, so that we can see the. old masters occasionally."
The, New York Telegram, answering the British press which bewailed the denuding of English
galleries and libraries by American
millionaires, said:
"Caxton, like Milton or Shakespeare, is as much an American
heritage as an English one; and it
is absurd for Englishmen, when in
good humor with us, to insist upon
the unity of certain preponderating
elements in our races and, when in
bad humor, to squeal if we get a
picture or so, or a manuscript from
some obscure, poverty-stricken or
whining peer.
"Many of the pictures which
have come over to us, and the loss
of which was bewailed as 'national,'
belonged to private persons and were
immured in country homes. They
had been obtained, moreover, by
purchase, in many cases, from foreign countries—from Holland, from
France and from Italy. It is no
terrible crime to sell to a foreign
country that which has been bought
from one. While bewailing the departure of art objects from England, the English sentimentalists
forget the purchase of the Elgin
marbles. These comprise no less a
treasure than the elaborately and
beautifully sculptured frieze of the
Parthenon, which Lord Elgin
bought from the Greek Government for the sum of i40,000. This
action has been denounced as vandalism ; but, (respite the denunciations, no English Government has
ever has the courage to propose
their restoration to Athens.
"It all depends, then, on whose
ox is gored."

Baseball is more subject to outside
influences than any other college
sport. The remarkable growth of the
great national game has been accompanied by an increasing lack of
ethics, and the college players, given
to a certain amount of emulation,
are beginning to adopt the spirit of
play shown by the professionals on
the diamond.
Professional baseball, at bottom,
is commercial; its primary object
is to make money for its backers.
Money can best be made when the
crowds are pleased, and to please
the crowds games must be won, no
matter by what means. And some
of these means have become objectionable. "Little tricks of the
trade," so to speak, have been employed to outwit opponents and win
games. Unfortunately, too, these
objectionable features have crept into the college game. Many persons
have deplored their introduction,
but have been unable to direct concerted corrective measures against
them.
The situation has reached that
point where some organized effort
must be made to get rid of the bad
features, and to this end a special
committee appointed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association
has made a study of conditions and
published a report in which recommendations are made that will tend
to prevent the introduction of the
so-called "professional spirit"into the
college sport. THE NEWS-LETTER
prints this report in full in another

THE NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 27, 1914.

THE N. C. A. ASSOCIATION
Recommendations and Regulations Intended for Adoption by American
College Baseball Teams.

The National Collegiate Athletic
Association, to which Dr. Ronald
T. Abercrombie is the Hopkins representative, has formulated the following recommendations and regulations which are intended for adoption by American college baseball
teams. The rules were prepared by
a special committee which studied
the baseball situation, and were accepted by the Association. It is
hoped that they will be put in force
throughout the country. The report of the committee follows:

the batsman or any member of the opposing team.
Second—No member .of either team
shall call or shout during the game to
any member of the opposing team, except to caution him against some danger,
nor behave in any indecorous or unseemly manner.
Third—There shall be no oral coaching from the bench.
Fourth — The so-called "encouragement of the pitcher" from the outfield
shall be stopped, or at least minimized,
since we believe that the shouting of remarks in endless iteration is not only
disagreeable to the spectators, but it is
disconcerting rather than helpful to the
pitcher. In general, it amounts merely to
senseless noise, and is quite unworthy
of college-bred men. Whatever "encouragement" or "support" the pitcher
may need can be quietly given from the
infield.
Fifth — The umpire shall warn any
player violating any of these rules, and
on a second offense shall exclude him
from the game.
Sixth—That in general the attention
of students be called to the importance
of courtesy on the part of the home institution to the visiting team, a courtesy
which will forbid such cheering, singing
or chatter as are designed at critical
moments to "rattle" the visiting team.
A baseball game is a splendid contest
of skill between two opposing nines, before an academic throng of spectators;
it is not a contest between a visiting
team and a local team assisted by a disorderly rabble. It is delightful when, as
often happens, a fine play by the visiting
team is as heartily applauded as a similar
play by the home team.
To the end that these principles, if endorsed by this Association, be a real
force and not a mere brutum fulmen, we
recommend that, if adopted, this report
be printed in separate form and copies
be sent by the secretary to the presidents, the deans, the athletic directors
or similar officers, the chairmen of faculty committees on athletic sports and to
the editors of .undergraduate publications of all colleges and universities aid
also to the leading preparatory schools
in the United States, with a formal request for action thereon and a report of
such action to the secretary of the Association.
Lours BErrry. JR., Chairman.

Your committee has for the time being nothing to do with the difficult question of eligibility, nor with summer ball
in its relation to amateur sport. It is
concerned with what is appropriate and
desirable in the conduct of the game
itself, in order that the manners of
officials, players and spectators may be
uniformly those of a gentleman, where
the highest ideals of fairness and sportsmanship shall be maintained, as is so admirably done in intercollegiate tennis.
We do not think that anything should
be recommended which would diminish
the virility of the game, or lessen the
scope of individual skill, or of clever
team-work, but we earnestly contend
that strategy must not deteriorate into
trickery, and that the rules of the game
must be observed, not only in letter,
but in spirit as well.
To this end, your committee recommends:
First—The strict enforcement of Rule
58 of the official rule book, which defines the coaching rules at first and
third bases, explicitly providing that "the
coacher shall be restricted to coaching
the base runner only, and shall not address remarks except to the base runner,
and then only in words of assistance and
direction in running bases. He shall not
by words or signs incite or try to incite
the spectators to demonstrations, and
shall not use language which will in any
manner refer to or reflect upon a player
of the opposite club, the umpire or the
spectators."
Second—The strict enforcement of

YALE WANTS TO CO TO WAR
(Continuedfrom page I.)
'I heir captain marched them around the
cage,
And marched them around again.
Thus some grew weary in one short day
(Though the nation had need of
them),
And these, when they softly stole away,
Left the company less by ten.
And ninety men of determined minds,
Ready to do and dare,
Lined up in the cage at the captain's
word,
And drilled with a martial air.
When some went out to an army camp,
To learn of the soldiers' fare—
When the company met for drill next
day,
There were only eighty there.
IV.
But the hearts of the eighty were firm
and strong,
And keen was their thirst for war;
Till a soldier who passed that way one
day,
Looked in at the open door,
And swore, with a laugh, that so awkward a squad,
He never had seen before.
This saddened the hearts of the eighty
men,
And ten of them drilled no more.
V.
Into the cage the seventy went,
Filled with a proud disdain;
"Let the faint-hearted go," they said,
"The best of us still remain."

BALTIMORE

But the news was spread of a mighty
fleet
Just sailed from the coast of Spain,
And ten of those who had marched out
that day
Were given and awful pain.
VI.
But sixty remained who laughed at fear,
And their hearts were light and gay,
Till the captain was asked by a practical
one,
"How much is a soldier's pay?"
And the captain, a blunt, straightforward
man,
Told them the truth that day;
The. company met for drill again,
But ten more stayed away.
VII.
'Twas thus with the noble company
That answered their country's call,
Their hearts were brave and their courage strong,
Even to fight and fall.
But numbers and patience and courage
alike
Faded from great to small,
For every day ten slippel away,
Until there were none at all.
VIII.
All honor those hundred Hopkins men,
That little, devoted band,
Though their names are not written in
brass and stone,
Nor lauded throughout the land;
For against the hungry tooth of time
Bravely they made their stand,
Till at last in their decimated ranks
There was not one left to disband.
